Posts.Content: Lunasin is a peptide derived from the soybean.  It's properties are not risky to breast cancer patients.  It is not a drug  - it's natural and we own the "exclusive rights" to it. Go to www.pubmed.com .  (this is the gov't monitored website where medical research is published)  On the search bar type in the words 'cancer and lunasin".  Over 50 studies are published - including breast cancer. If you don't think this is worth it - think again about the success rate of allopathic treatments.  Surgery (Mastectomies) chemo; radiation; etc...  There is over an 80% failure rate for patients diagnosed 7 yrs or less.  By the year 2020 1 in 2 women will experience a cancer diagnosis sometime in their lifetime.  (Breast cancer being #1).  This info was supplied by actuarial sciences used by insurance companies.   Become educated about this - not opinionated!  I've helped tons of women.  Don't listen to me - listen to them! Epigenetics!  Turn the bad genes off and turn the good genes on!

Posts.Content: Oncologists make 60% of their income from the drug treatments they prescribe.  (And everyone accepts that!)  My company invested $$millions to develop lunasin,which has been proven to work, but are we suppose to give it away?   You're asking for an alternative, yes you're scared, but reject what is out there - without knowing anything about it.  Because doctors don't know about it doesn't mean it doesn't work.  Again, go to www.pubmed.com and type in the search bar "cancer and  lunasin".  Over 50 studies are posted how this helps.  Doctors can't make $$ from lunasin because we own the rights to it - so they won't endorse it.   Surviving cancer beyond 7 years after initial diagnosis is very rare.  Those that do survive are in the minority and did so by changing their diet, becoming alkaline, avoiding sugar, exercise regularly and make good lifestyle choices.  Drs don't make $$ telling patients to alkaline their bodies and changing their diets, - they do it by prescribing allopathic treatments. Almost all drugs are synthetic - not natural.  If you know any acturial scientists, ask them about what we're talking about.  I know 3 life insurance salesmen,who all work for different companies, and they all said that this is true what the acturials have researched. I want to help people -this may not be the right place to do it, however, if you're looking for more than what you're getting right now , what is it you want?  How can I help you?

Posts.Content: Lunasin DOES NOT contain any soy.  That info was mentioned several times by Dr. Galvez.  Here's his response: There have been requests to repost my personal view and the link to an article on the safety of soy ... Several people have asked for my own view on whether soy is safe or not. Here's my response as a scientist: There is a fundamental difference between the training of physicians and scientists. Physicians are trained to be decisive, even in the face of incomplete information. Scientists are trained to be skeptical, even in the face of (apparently) overwhelming data. To drive home this point, let me use as an example the effect of soy consumption on breast cancer. In the early 2000s, Dr. William Helferich, a nutrition scientist at the University of Illinois, published a series of papers on the effect of genistein, a phytoestrogen found in soy, on promoting the growth of human breast cancer cells in mice (whose ovaries where removed to get rid of endogenous estrogen). His research was sensationalized by the media, and to this day, has been used by anti-soy proponents as an example of the "dangers of soy" and by physicians to recommend to their patients NOT to consume soy. Dr. Helferich, being a scientist, knows that the relationship between soy and breast cancer is much more complex than what his initial research has suggested. He did more research and in 2010 published with other scientists a review article on this subject: Is soy consumption good or bad to the breast? (you can read the whole article in link). Portion of their abstract states, "Results suggest that women consuming moderate amounts of soy throughout their life have lower breast cancer risk than women who do not consume soy .... Findings obtained in 2 recent human studies show that a moderate consumption of diet containing this isoflavone (genistein), does not increase the risk of breast cancer recurrence in Western women, and Asian breast cancer survivors exhibit better prognosis". And in direct correlation with my work on lunasin, they further conclude, "We propose that the reduction in (breast cancer) risk involves epigenetic changes that result in alterations in the expression of genes that regulate mammary epithelial cell fate, i.e. cell proliferation and differentiation". http://jn.nutrition.org/content/140/12/2326S.long
